questions.question: Which of the following hormones is not secreted by the ovary?
questions.explanation: Gonadotropins are secreted by the pituitary gland, not the ovary.

questions.question: A 30-year-old lady has regular, infrequent menstrual cycles occurring at an interval of 35-36days. What is the usual timing of ovulation in this lady?
questions.explanation: Ovulation occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length.If we calculate the day of menstruation from the beginning of the cycle, in a 28-day cycle,ovulation occurs on day 14 and in a 35-day cycle, ovulation will occur on day 22.791Option B: LH surge leads to ovulation. Ovulation does not occur before LH surge.Option C: The ruptured ovarian follicle (after ovulation) is converted into corpus luteum.Ovulation does not occur after corpus luteal maturation.Option D: Ovulation will occur 14 days before menstruation, i.e. on day 22 of a 35-day cycle. Itdoes not occur 22 days before menstruation.

questions.question: The corpus luteum starts regressing after how many days post ovulation?
questions.explanation: The human corpus luteum starts regressing ~10 days after ovulation.Ovulation occurs on day 14, and the day corpus luteum begins to regress on day 25 of themenstrual cycle.Therefore,Days after ovulation when corpus luteum starts regressing = 25-14 = 11 daysThe human corpus luteum is programmed to live for 14 days, plus or minus 2 days (corpus luteumof menstruation).Figure Events of the menstrual cycle:Ovarian events in menstrual cycleUterinebleedingBleedingstartsFollicularphaseDay 114Lutealphase2526Multiple folliclesdevelopDominantfollicle maturesCorpus luteumfunctionsCorpus luteumdegeneratesOne folliclebecomesdominantOvulationOMARROW

questions.question: Which of the following is not seen in humans?
questions.explanation: Estrous cycle is not seen in humans. Mammals other than primates do not menstruate, and their sexual cycle is called an estrous cycle. It is named for the conspicuous period of “heat” (estrus) at the time of ovulation, normally the only time during which the sexual interest of the female is aroused. In spontaneously ovulating species with estrous cycles, such as the rat, no episodic vaginal bleeding occurs, but the underlying endocrine events are essentially the same as those in the menstrual cycle. In other species, ovulation is induced by copulation (reflex ovulation).

questions.question: Which of the following is the dominant hormone in the luteal phase?
questions.explanation: • Progesterone is the dominant hormone during the luteal phase.•⚫ The corpus luteum in the non-pregnant woman secretes large quantities of progesterone and asmall amount of estrogen, as well as inhibin..• In terms of ovarian function, the menstrual cycle may be divided into two phases approximatelyequal in length and separated by ovulation (Figure):•• The follicular phase, during which a mature follicle and secondary oocyte develop; and• The luteal phase begins after ovulation and lasts until the death of the corpus luteum.Ovarian events in menstrual cycleUterinebleedingBleedingstartsFollicularphaseDay714Lutealphase2526Multiple folliclesDominantdevelopfollicle maturesfunctionsCorpus luteum Corpus luteumdegeneratesOne folliclebecomesdominantOvulationOMARROWFollicular phase (days 0-14)• A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.⚫ LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in theca and granulosa cells.•• Estradiol levels increase and cause proliferation of the uterus..• FSH and LH levels are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol on the anteriorpituitary.• Progesterone levels are low.Ovulation (day 14)• Occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. Thus, in a 28-day cycle, ovulationoccurs on day 14; in a 35-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 22.793• A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect onthe secretion of FSH and LH (LH surge).• Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.• Estrogen levels decrease just after ovulation (but rise again during the luteal phase).••Cervical mucus increases in quantity; it becomes less viscous and more penetrable by sperm.Luteal phase (days 14-28)⚫ The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularityand secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for receipt of a fertilized egg.•Basal body temperature increases because of the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamicthermoregulatory center.••If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As aresult, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.Menses (days 0-4)• The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesteroneDAYSFOLLICULAR PHASE36.7"BASAL BODYTEMPERATURE36.4°HORMONE LEVELFSHLHESTROGENPROGESTERONE14OVARIAN CYCLEOVULATION2128LUTEAL PHASEOVUMYYYYYUTERINE CYCLEMENSES PROLIFERATIVE |SECRETORY794Relationship between ovarian and uterinechanges during the menstrual cycleOvarianeventEndometrialthicknessDayUterinephaseOvarianphase1FollicleMenstrualOvulationCorpus luteumOvumEstrogenProgesteroneEstrogen51015202528ProliferativeSecretoryFollicularOMARROWMenstrualLutealFollicular

questions.question: Which of the following hormones is responsible for the maintenance of endometrial thicknessin the post-ovulatory phase?
questions.explanation: Progesterone is mainly responsible for the maintenance of endometrial thickness in thepost-ovulatory phase.The menstrual cycle consists of three phases: the menstrual phase, the proliferative phase, and thesecretory, or progestational, phaseMenstrual phase: This phase is characterized by the discharge of blood and endometrial debrisfrom the vagina.•It coincides with the end of the ovarian luteal phase and onset of a new follicular phase.• Withdrawal of progesterone on the degeneration of the corpus luteum (CL) leads simultaneouslyto sloughing of the endometrium (menstruation) and development of new follicles in the ovaryunder the influence of rising gonadotropic hormone levelsProliferative Phase: Thus, menstrual flow ceases, and the proliferative phase of the uterine cyclebegins concurrently with the last portion of the ovarian follicular phase.• When the menstrual flow ceases, a thin endometrial layer less than 1-mm thick remains.Estrogen stimulates proliferation of epithelial cells, glands, and blood vessels in the endometrium,increasing this lining to a thickness of 3 to 5 mm.• The estrogen-dominant proliferative phase lasts from the end of menstruation to ovulation. Peakestrogen levels trigger the luteinizing hormone (LH) surge responsible for ovulation.Secretory or Progestational Phase: After ovulation, when a new corpus luteum is formed, theuterus enters the secretory, or progestational, phase, which coincides in time with the ovarianluteal phase. The corpus luteum secretes large amounts of progesterone and estrogen.Progesterone converts the thickened, estrogen-primed endometrium to a richly vascularized,glycogen-filled tissue.•This period is called either the secretory phase, because the endometrial glands are activelysecreting glycogen into the uterine lumen for early nourishment of a developing embryo before it795implants, or the progestational ("before pregnancy") phase, referring to the development of a lushendometrial lining capable of supporting an early embryo after implantation.• If fertilization and implantation do not occur, the corpus luteum degenerates and a newfollicular phase and menstrual phase begin again.

questions.question: A couple is planning to conceive by artificial intrauterine insemination (IUI). In order to ensure optimal timing for intrauterine transfer of husband's sperm, the wife is advised to use a home-based ovulation predictor kit. Detecting which of the following hormones in urine is the purpose of this kit?
questions.explanation: Detection of an increased LH level in urine will be performed by this ovulation predictor kit. The most important physiological marker of imminent ovulation is luteinizing hormone (LH) surge, which is characterized by an increased level of LH in serum and urine. A peak level of 75 ng/mL of LH in serum is required for ovulation. LH surge occurs 24-36 hours before ovulation. LH peak lasts 24 hours. LH surge causes the following: • Completion of meiosis of ovum • Ovulation • Development of corpus luteum

questions.question: 784Positive feedback action of estrogen for inducing luteinizing hormone surge is associated withwhich of the following steroid hormone ratio in peripheral circulation?
questions.explanation: Positive feedback action of estrogen for inducing luteinizing hormone (LH) surge is associatedwith high estrogen: low progesterone.Phases HormoneType of feedbackSiteFSH and LH secretionFolliculEstrogenNegativeAnterior pituitaryBoth suppressedarMidcyclEstrogenPositiveAnterior pituitaryIncreased LH surgeLutealEstrogen Progestero NegativeNegatiNegativeNegatineveAnterior pituitaryAnterior pituitaryBoth are decreased

questions.question: Which of the following best explains the mechanism behind an increase in LH secretion justbefore ovulation ?
questions.explanation: Increased luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion just before ovulation is due to positive feedback byestrogen.796PhasesHormoneType of feedbaSiteckFolliculEstrogenNegativeAnterior pituitaryFSH and LH secretionBoth suppressedarMidcyclEstrogenPositiveAnterior pituitaryIncreased LH surgeeLutealneveEstrogen Progestero NegativeNegati Anterior pituitaryAnterior pituitaryBoth are decreased

questions.question: Corpus luteum of pregnancy is maintained by.
questions.explanation: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG) causes persistence of the corpus luteum and preventsmenstruation in pregnancy.The fate of the corpus luteum• If the ovum is not fertilized, about 2 days before the end of the monthly cycle, the corpus luteumin the ovary involutes• If fertilization occurs, under the influence of human chorionic gonadotropin, the corpus luteumin the mother's ovary grows to about twice its initial size by a month or so after pregnancy begins•The corpus luteum secretes estrogens and progesterone and maintains the decidual nature of theuterine endometrium, which is necessary for the early development of the fetus• The corpus luteum of pregnancy involutes slowly after the 13th to 17th week of gestation. Afterthat time, the placenta secretes sufficient quantities of progesterone and estrogens to maintainpregnancy for the remainder of the gestation period

questions.question: FSH receptor is present in_
questions.explanation: .•Granulosa cells express the FSH receptor.Theca interna cells express LH receptor.Theca interna cells have many LH receptors. LH acts via cAMP to increase conversion ofcholesterol to androstenedione. The theca interna cells supply androstenedione to the granulosacells. The granulosa cells make estradiol when provided with androgens.Granulosa cells have many FSH receptors. FSH facilitates their secretion of estradiol by acting viaCAMP to increase their aromatase activity. Mature granulosa cells also acquire LH receptors, andLH also stimulates estradiol production.

questions.question: 785A 30-year-old lady is using the basal body temperature method for contraception. She takesnote of a rise in her body temperature for abstinence during the fertile period. The increase inbasal body temperature in the mid-luteal phase is due to which of the following hormones?
questions.explanation: 797An increase in basal body temperature in the mid-luteal phase is due to the effect of progesteroneon the hypothalamic thermoregulatory centre.Immediately after ovulation, corpus luteum is formed, which secretes progesterone in preparationof the body for potential pregnancy during that cycle. This progesterone acts on the hypothalamusand increases basal body temperature. Charting the daily basal body temperature will show anincrease of approximately 0.5 to 1 degrees fahrenheit shortly after ovulation.Since the rise in basal body temperature coincides with ovulation, abstaining from sexualintercourse until at least 3 days after the woman's temperature has risen above her regulartemperature significantly lowers the chance of pregnancy. Alternatively, using barriermethods (e.g. condom, diaphragm) during this time will prevent pregnancy.However several factors (e.g fever, sleep deprivation etc.) that change the basal body temperature,can affect the efficacy and reliability of this method.

questions.question: A blood sample is drawn on day 20 of the menstrual cycle of a young woman undergoing evaluation for irregular menstruation. Serum level of which of the following hormones helps in assessing whether her cycle was ovulatory or not?
questions.explanation: Whether her cycle was ovulatory or not can be validly assessed by the reported serum level of progesterone. Day 20 usually corresponds to the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle. In case of anovulatory cycles, no corpus luteum will be formed and so progesterone levels will be low. Hence, progesterone levels are valuable to predict if the cycles were ovulatory or not.

questions.question: Secretion of estrogen is maximum
questions.explanation: • Estrogen comes from the ovary, and two peaks of secretion occur one just before ovulation andone during the mid-luteal phase.•• After menopause, estrogen secretion declines to low levels.DAYS7FOLLICULAR PHASE36.7BASAL BODYTEMPERATURE36.4HORMONE LEVELFSHLHESTROGENPROGESTERONE142128LUTEAL PHASEOVARIAN CYCLEOVULATIONUTERINE CYCLEOVUMYYYYYMENSES PROLIFERATIVE |SECRETORY798

questions.question: Which of the following hormones inhibit FSH and LH secretion in the luteal phase?
questions.explanation: Estrogen inhibits FSH and LH secretion in the luteal phase.Feedback regulation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axisLuteal phase: the corpus luteum secretes large quantities of progesterone and estrogen. They exerta negative feedback effect on the anterior pituitary gland causing the suppression of both FSH andLH secretion.Preovulatory period: The high level of estrogens at this time (or the beginning of progesteronesecretion by the follicles) causes a positive feedback stimulatory effect on the anterior pituitaryleading to a surge of LH and to a lesser extent, FSH.Follicular phase: secretion of estrogen, progesterone from the corpus luteum decreases whichleads to loss of negative feedback effect of these hormones on the anterior pituitary. Therefore,pituitary secretion of FSH begins to increase again, as much as twofold. LH secretion increasesslightly as well.GnRH stimulates FSH and LH secretion. Growth hormone and IGF may cause an increase in FSHand LH levels.

questions.question: Which of the following statements can be regarded as the primary action of inhibin?
questions.explanation: The inhibins inhibit FSH secretion by the gonadotrophs of the anterior pituitary (hence the name inhibin) in a classic negative feedback arrangement.

questions.question: Inhibin B is secreted by_
questions.explanation: The inhibins are produced by the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle, as well as other tissues,including the pituitary, the brain, the adrenal gland, the kidney, the bone marrow, the corpusluteum, and the placenta. Inhibin A is produced by the corpus luteum whereas inhibin B is mainlyproduced by granulosa cells of the follicleFSH specifically stimulates the granulosa cells to produce inhibins.Just before ovulation, after the granulosa cells acquire LH receptors, LH also stimulates theproduction of inhibin by granulosa cells.

questions.question: Source of progesterone during normal menstrual cycle_
questions.explanation: The source of progesterone during the normal menstrual cycle is corpus luteum.Progesterone is also secreted by the placenta, and the ovarian follicle (in small amounts).799

questions.question: Which of the following is the source of estrogen?
questions.explanation: Estrogen are secreted primarily by the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicles, the corpus luteum,and the placenta.

questions.question: 787Regarding the two-cell-two-gonadotropin hypothesis which of the following is true?

options.A: FSH and LH inhibits the release of estrogen and progesterone
options.B: FSH acts on granulosa cells and LH on theca cells
options.C: FSH stimulates estrogen while LH inhibits estrogen
options.D: FSH feedback inhibits hypothalamus while LH feedback inhibits pituitary

questions.explanation: The two-cell-two-gonadotropin hypothesis:•Estradiol synthesis requires the contribution of two distinct cell types:• The theca and granulosa cells within the follicle and• The theca-lutein and granulosa lutein cells within the corpus luteum•The follicular theca cells, under the control of LH, produce androgens that diffuse to thefollicular granulosa cells, where they are converted to estrogens via an FSH-supportedaromatization reaction. The granulosa cells cannot convert progesterone to androstenedionebecause of the lack of the enzyme 17° -hydroxylase.

questions.question: Regarding the action of progesterone which of the following is true?

options.A: Increases sensitivity of uterus to oxytocin
options.D: Causes marked proliferative changes in uterus

questions.explanation: Progesterone inhibits LH secretion.Actions of progesterone•Has negative feedback effects on FSH and LH secretion during the luteal phase.• Maintains secretory activity of the uterus during the luteal phase.• Maintains pregnancy.• Raises the uterine threshold to contractile stimuli during pregnancy, i.e decreases sensitivity ofthe uterus to oxytocin.•Participates in the development of the breasts.• Increases body temperature• It stimulates respiration, and the alveolar PCO2 in women during the luteal phase of themenstrual cycle is lower than that in men.• Large doses of progesterone produce natriuresis, probably by blocking the action of aldosteroneon the kidney.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most potent type of estrogen found in women of reproductiveage group?
questions.explanation: 800• Estradiol is the most abundant in the reproductive age group and is 12 and 80 times morepotent than estrone and estriol respectively.• The principal sex steroids in females are estrogen, progestin, and androgen. Three estrogens arepresent in significant quantities-estradiol, estrone, and estriol.

questions.question: Which is the predominant estrogen in the plasma of premenopausal non-pregnant women?
questions.explanation: Estradiol is the predominant estrogen in the plasma of premenopausal non-pregnant women. It isprimarily secreted from ovaries.Estrone is synthesized from dehydroepiandrosterone in adipose tissue stroma. Estrone is theabundant circulating form of estrogen in postmenopausal women.In pregnancy, the placenta uses dehydroepiandrosterone and its 16 alpha hydroxyl derivative toform large amounts of estrone and estriol.

questions.question: 788Which of the following is false about estrogen action?

options.A: Development of secondary sexual characters in female

questions.explanation: Estrogen does not stimulate osteoclast. Rather it prevents osteoporosis by inhibiting osteoclasticactivity.Actions of Estrogen⚫ Causes maturation and maintenance of the fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and vagina.• Causes proliferation and development of ovarian granulosa cells.• Proliferation of endometrium• Causes the development of female secondary sex characteristics at puberty.• Maintains pregnancy.• Lowers the uterine threshold to contractile stimuli during pregnancy.•Causes the ductal development of the breasts.• Has both negative and positive feedback effects on FSH and LH secretion.•Up-regulates estrogen, LH, and progesterone receptors.• Increases secretion of angiotensinogen and thyroid binding globulin•⚫ Epiphyseal closure of long bones• Increase libido by acting on the hypothalamus.• Salt and water retention before menstruation•↓LDL cholesterol• ↑ the local production of NO→vasodilation••Inhibit osteoclast, prevent osteoporosis801

questions.question: A 12-year-old girl is undergoing pubertal changes. Her tanner stage is stage 4 for breastdevelopment and pubic hair scale. Which of the following pubertal changes is not due toestrogen?
questions.explanation: Pubarche or development of axillary and pubic hair is not due to estrogen. It is due to testosterone(in both the sexes).Puberty in females:• Involves the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche), breast development (thelarche), and anincrease in adrenal androgen secretion (adrenarche).• Estradiol induces the development of secondary sex characteristics, including the breasts andreproductive tract, and increased fat in the hips.• Estrogens also regulate the growth spurt at puberty, vaginal cornification and cervical mucusproduction, induce closure of the epiphyses, have a positive effect in maintaining bone formation,and can antagonize the degrading actions of parathyroid hormone on bone.

questions.question: ẞ HCG is secreted by which of the following organs?
questions.explanation: ẞ HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is secreted by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta.Some important features of ẞ HCG:•⚫ hCG is a glycoprotein that contains galactose and hexosamine.• It is produced by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta.•It is made up of ° and ẞ subunits.⚫hCG-° is identical to the ° subunit of LH, FSH, and TSH.•⚫ hCG is primarily luteinizing and luteotropic and has little FSH activity.•• Its presence in early pregnancy in urine is the basis of the various laboratory tests for pregnancy,and it can sometimes be detected in the urine as early as 14 days after conception.

questions.question: Progesterone has how many carbon atoms?
questions.explanation: Progesterone has 21 carbon atoms.

questions.question: 789Which of the following is false about milk ejection?

options.A: The neuroendocrine part of anterior pituitary is involved.
options.B: Its secretion occurs by contraction of lactiferous sinus.

questions.explanation: The neuroendocrine part of the anterior pituitary is not involved in milk ejection. The posteriorpituitary is involved in milk ejection reflex.The posterior pituitary secretes oxytocin, which is responsible for milk ejection. The anteriorpituitary produces prolactin, which is responsible for lactogenesis.802Figure: Milk Ejection ReflexIncreased milk production triggersIncreased suckling by infant(positive feedback loop).Suckling triggers sensory nerve impulses in the areola.Brain receives sensory impulses from theareola and releases oxytocin (OT) fromthe hypothalamus and posterior pituitary.Neurosecretorycells of supraopticnucleusLactocytes in mammary alveoli producemilk in response to sensory nerve impulsos.Hypothalamo-hypophyseal tractAnteriorpituitaryGT releaseOxytocin (OT) triggers myoepithelial cells tosqueeze milk from alveoli so it drains intolactiferous ducts.AlveolusMilk transportCapillaryplexusOT releaseOTOTOTMammaryglandscontainingalveoliLactiferous ductsMilk is pooled in lactiferous sinusbefore being discharged throughnipple pores,Lactiferous sinusMilk Ejection ReflexSucklingMechanoreceptors in nippleNervous pathwayHypothalamusPosterior pituitary†OxytocinContraction ofmyoepithelial cellssurrounding alveoliMilk ojectionEjectionAnterior pituitarySecretionMilkOMARROW+ ProlactinSecretion byalveolar epithelialcells+ Milk secretion

questions.question: Which of the following hormones is responsible for milk ejection?
questions.explanation: •Oxytocin causes contraction of the myoepithelial cells lining the mammary ducts and ejects milkduring suckling. But, it has no galactogenic effect.• Prolactin is responsible for milk secretion.• Estrogens are primarily responsible for the proliferation of the mammary ducts and theprogesterone for the development of lobules.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a function of oxytocin?
questions.explanation: 803Lactogenesis is not a function of oxytocin. It is caused by prolactin.804
